messageBody:
On 10/30/05, Elliotte Harold <elharo@...> wrote:
>
> Kent Beck wrote:
>
> > In general, I prefer to make all non-externally-visible methods
> protected,
> > since I don't know a priori which ones will prove useful as hooks for
> > further extension.
>
> Basic OOP: keep everything as private as you possibly can.


Basic real world: you can never anticipate how future users will use your
software, so don't make their lives too difficult.

While I sympathize with the idea of keeping as much private as possible, I
am also a bit bothered by the patronizing feeling behind it. Developers
don't need baby-sitting and a lot of them are very capable to know the
consequences of their decisions. Reusing a protected method is dangerous --
especially if this method has been documented with a lot of warnings -- but
this doesn't mean it should be banned altogether.

Between code that I cannot reuse at all and code that I can reuse but that
might break in the future, I will take my chances with the latter any day.


This gives you maximum flexibility for future development and change.


Fair enough: it gives *you* the maximum flexibility. Declaring these
methods protected gives *them* the maximum flexibility. There is no clear
winner: just make this decision responsibly, and not because it's written
in bold in the Agile manifesto.


Basic Agile: You Ain't Going to Need It (YAGNI).


Is it written in bold too? :-)

--
Cédric
